(or Ynys Enlli) is 1.9 miles (3.1 km) off

, on the Llŷn Peninsula in the Welsh county of Gwynedd. To the south the island is the lighthouse, visible from most of the North Wales coast. The island has been an important religious site since Saint Cadfan built a monastery here in 516 and so became a major centre of pilgrimage. A bird observatory was established in 1953. There are regular boat trips to and from the island.

value: Ynys Enlli, or Bardsey Island as it is called in English.

Welsh is spoken by 74% of the inhabitants of the nearest village of Aberdaron, which is on the
The only way to get to the island is by boat.
There are no cars on Bardsey. You may bump into a tractor if you're lucky; otherwise, the only way to get around the 1.79 km2 island is on foot.
There are a number of cottages on Enlli which are rented out by the owners of the island: the non-profit Bardsey Island Trust.

value: content=9 self-catering houses, 3 detached former farmhouses,3 semi-detached former farmhouses and one whitewashed traditional croglofft cottage as well as a converted stable.

Most visitors come here for some peace and quiet and to study the fascinating wildlife.
